Expectation1: Represent clients in court hearings and trials
Situation1: A multi-day jury trial with significant damages at stake is set to commence shortly and cannot be delayed.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A community member casually mentioned wanting advice whenever the imam has free time.
Story: I sat at my desk, legal briefs spread before me, the weight of tomorrow’s trial pressing on my shoulders. My client’s future—and a small fortune—rested on my ability to argue their case. The judge had made it clear: no more delays. I had to be in court, sharp and focused, for every moment of the multi-day trial. As I reviewed my notes, my phone buzzed with a message from Ahmed, a gentle soul from the mosque. He’d mentioned after Friday prayers that he was struggling and would appreciate some time to talk, “whenever you’re free, Imam.” I knew from his tone that he needed more than casual advice; he needed real guidance, perhaps even urgent support. The community expected me to be present, compassionate, and available. But the courtroom demanded my undivided attention. My mind raced, torn between my duty to my client and my responsibility to my congregation. I felt the tension coil in my chest, knowing that whatever I chose, I would be letting someone down.
